Detailed Description

DLB device capability flags.

Member Data Documentation

◆ combined_credits

uint64_t dlb_dev_cap_t::combined_credits

The device supports a combined load-balanced and directed credit pool. When this flag is set, the user only needs a single credit pool for sending both load-balanced and directed events.

◆ ldb_deq_event_fid

uint64_t dlb_dev_cap_t::ldb_deq_event_fid

The device places the flow ID in the dequeued load-balanced event. When this flag is set, the device fills dlb_ldb_recv_t's flow_id field with the enqueued flow ID.

◆ lock_id_comp

uint64_t dlb_dev_cap_t::lock_id_comp

The device supports lock ID compression. When this flag is set, each queue can be configured to hash and compress lock IDs in order to fit more concurrent flows in the device's atomic storage area, at the (potential) cost of increased average flow pinning duration.

◆ op_frag

uint64_t dlb_dev_cap_t::op_frag

The device supports event fragmentation. When a thread is processing an ordered event, it can perform up to 16 partial enqueues, which allows a single received ordered event to result in multiple reordered events.

◆ port_cos

uint64_t dlb_dev_cap_t::port_cos

The device supports multiple load-balanced port scheduling classes-of- service (CoS). The device defines four classes, each with a percentage of guaranteed scheduling bandwidth (25% per class by default) with any unreserved bandwidth shared between all classes.

For devices with this capability, ports from specific classes of service can be reserved when creating the a scheduling domain and a desired CoS can be specified when creating a load-balanced port.

◆ qe_weight

uint64_t dlb_dev_cap_t::qe_weight

The device supports weight-based scheduling. This must be enabled for each port by calling dlb_enable_cq_weight().

See also
dlb_enable_cq_weight for more details

◆ queue_dt

uint64_t dlb_dev_cap_t::queue_dt

The device supports queue depth threshold indicators. When this flag is set, each queue can be configured with a threshold, and the dequeue event's qdi field indicates the queue's depth relative to that threshold.
